verses.verse: Dead<WH4194> flies<WH2070> cause the oil<WH8081> of the perfumer<WH7543> to send forth<WH5042> an evil odor;<WH887> so does a little<WH4592> folly<WH5531> outweigh<WH3368> wisdom<WH2451> and honor.<WH3519>
A wise man<WH2450>'s heart<WH3820> is at his right hand,<WH3225> but a fool<WH3684>'s heart<WH3820> at his left.<WH8040>
Yes also,<WH5530> when the fool walks<WH1980> by the way,<WH1870> his understanding<WH3820> fails<WH2638> him,<WH559> and he says to everyone that he is a fool.<WH5530>
If the spirit<WH7307> of the ruler<WH4910> rises up<WH5927> against you,<WH3240> don't leave your place;<WH4725> for gentleness<WH4832> lays<WH3240> great<WH1419> offenses to rest.<WH2399>
There is<WH3426> an evil<WH7451> which I have seen<WH7200> under the sun,<WH8121> the sort of error<WH7684> which proceeds<WH3318> from<WH6440> the ruler.<WH7989>
Folly<WH5529> is set<WH5414> in great<WH7227> dignity,<WH4791> and the rich<WH6223> sit<WH3427> in a low place.<WH8216>
I have seen<WH7200> servants<WH5650> on horses,<WH5483> and princes<WH8269> walking<WH1980> like servants<WH5650> on the earth.<WH776>
He who digs<WH2658> a pit<WH1475> may fall<WH5307> into it;<WH6555> and whoever breaks through a wall<WH1447> may be bitten<WH5391> by a snake.<WH5175>
Whoever carves out<WH5265> stones<WH68> may be injured<WH6087> by them.<WH1234> Whoever splits wood<WH6086> may be endangered thereby.<WH5533>
If the axe<WH1270> is blunt,<WH6949> and one doesn't<WH7043> sharpen the edge,<WH6440> then he must use<WH1396> more strength;<WH2428> but skill<WH2451> brings<WH3787> success.<WH3504>
If the snake<WH5175> bites<WH5391> before it is charmed,<WH3908> then is there no profit<WH3504> for the charmer<WH3956>'s tongue.
The words<WH1697> of a wise man<WH2450>'s mouth<WH6310> are gracious;<WH2580> but a fool<WH3684> is swallowed<WH1104> by his own lips.<WH8193>
The beginning<WH8462> of the words<WH1697> of his mouth<WH6310> is foolishness;<WH5531> and the end<WH319> of his talk<WH6310> is mischievous<WH7451> madness.<WH1948>
A fool<WH5530> also multiplies<WH7235> words.<WH1697> Man<WH120> doesn't<WH3045> know what will be;<WH310> and that which will be after him,<WH5046> who can tell him?
The labor<WH5999> of fools<WH3684> wearies<WH3021> every one of them;<WH3045> for he doesn't know how to go<WH3212> to the city.<WH5892>
Woe<WH337> to you,<WH776> land, when your king<WH4428> is a child,<WH5288> and your princes<WH8269> eat<WH398> in the morning!<WH1242>

Happy<WH835> are you,<WH776> land, when your king<WH4428> is the son<WH1121> of nobles,<WH2715> and your princes<WH8269> eat<WH398> in due season,<WH6256> for strength,<WH1369> and not for drunkenness!<WH8358>
By slothfulness<WH6103> the roof<WH4746> sinks<WH4355> in;<WH8220> and through idleness of the hands<WH3027> the house<WH1004> leaks.<WH1811>
A feast<WH3899> is made<WH6213> for laughter,<WH7814> and wine<WH3196> makes the life glad;<WH8055> and money<WH3701> is the answer for all things.<WH6030>

Don't<WH7043> curse the king,<WH4428> no,<WH4093> not in your thoughts; and don't<WH7043> curse the rich<WH6223> in your bedroom:<WH2315> for a bird<WH5775> of the sky<WH8064> may carry<WH3212> your voice,<WH6963> and that which has<WH1167> wings<WH3671> may tell<WH5046> the matter.<WH1697>
